common_questions: When to walk away from an interview process?
explaining what a particular function did, after they had told me to comment everything
explain to me why you rejected the last person you interviewed"
explain that, but I’ll keep reapplying and working towards it until I get it
interview_tips: throwing your effort towards learning JavaScript and possibly a common front end framework such as React, Vue, Angular (probably not this)
filing for unemployment immediately and not next week
is given that initially gives interview of companies which you won't join mostly so you will have interview experience
to toggle on reasoning mode in settings if you expect to get leetcode hards for far better answers
your portfolio website is showcasing your best work in a clear and concise way
you tailor it to whatever position you’re applying for, but don’t lie about yourself either
to look at other schools, especially your local community college
your code skills are at a level that fits in with an employer's needs and ability to train
red_flags: lose hope because I was on the same path
know where you get them from because there are too many courses, and they don't have time to check
be afraid to apply even if you don't have any projects of your own
feel discouraged if you feel like they are too much beyond your ability
HAVE to give feedback to their candidates but the fact that you took up 10 hours of my time after reaching out to me and don't have the decency to tel
feel like this is a sub where I need to post my outbound materials - they've been edited, reviewed, and I think they're okay
mind slumming if that's what it takes to make a buck, and I'm not a big salary addict
be scared of trying and learning new skills

process_insights.format: Mix of phone screen, technical, behavioral, on-site, virtual
